thread.section_title: Finance | Business and Finance News | News.com.au
thread.title: More public-owned homes in Millers Point to go to auction
thread.title_full: More public-owned homes in Millers Point to go to auction

author: Aidan Devine
title: More public-owned homes in Millers Point to go to auction
text:
SIX more public houses have come up for sale in Millers Point, following hot on the heels of the landmark $4.3 million sale of a government-owned cottage on Argyle Street in May.
The sales are part of a multi-million dollar initiative to sell off public housing assets in the inner city, constituting the biggest single release in the program to date.
58 Kent St, Millers Point is part of the release and was built in 1877. Source: Supplied
The interior of 58 Kent Street. The property next door, 56 Kent, is nearly identical and recently sold for $1.68 million. Source: Supplied
The heritage-listed properties are due to go to auction August 25 and include two 19 century terraces on Trinity Avenue and four additional terraces on Kent Street, the oldest of which was built in 1871. 40 Kent St is also part of the release. Source: Supplied
The interior of 40 Kent St also needs renovating. Source: Supplied
Government Property NSW chief executive Brett Newman said the six homes were released at once to take advantage of strong market conditions. Since launching the sell-off more than a year ago, the NSW Government has sold 23 former public houses, with most selling between $1.6 million and $2.5 million.
Combined, the sales have totalled more than $50 million.
84 Kent St, Millers Point. Properties nearby have sold in the region of $1.9 million. Source: Supplied
The terrace comprises four grand brick and stucco terraces built on land purchased in 1867. Source: Supplied
Publicly owned for 100 years, the four-bedroom terrace at 84 Kent St is offered for sale with the opportunity to recreate its former glory. Source: Supplied
“It’s the first time six Millers Point properties have been listed and sold concurrently, reflecting strong market confidence,” Mr Newman said. Proceeds from the auctions will be reinvested into 1500 new social housing dwellings in other parts of Sydney and regional NSW.
Raine and Horne Double Bay is marketing the six properties and selling agent Jeremy Clinton said they would most likely appeal to owner-occupiers looking for an alternative to inner city apartments.
22 Trinity Ave, Millers Point was built circa 1898. Source: Supplied
“Most of the interest in these homes is coming from downsizers who want to renovate the properties and live there. Investors haven’t been as interested,” Mr Clinton said. He added that some of the homes require more renovations than others, but all are being sold with a Conservation Management Plan endorsed by the Heritage Council to guide restoration and repair work.
20 Trinity Ave, Millers Point is going to auction August 25. Source: Supplied
Similar properties that have recently sold in the area suggest that the homes should sell anywhere between $1.6 million and $1.9 million.
